In the Commons yesterday, the Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority said, in response to questions from the British government, that on Tuesday a Cabinet member sent the committee six "negative" emails, including one in which a member said the chairman was "hurt and humiliated".

But in a statement following the meeting, Mr Johnson said in the committee's report: "I am so gratified that the committee has received so many positive messages from cabinet members and MPs who are in the midst of a fantastic day of reform.

The committee have made the case for a thorough report by its members, and in particular, for a fair, independent, independent, independent and impartial review of the information contained in these emails.

The committee does not believe that the emails contain any evidence of wrongdoing and have been examined for evidence of many of the issues that are raised by the committee.

I would like to take this opportunity to apologise unreservedly to the committee members for the difficulties they have caused me and my colleagues.

I fully intend to follow through with my mandate. I am not going to hold up the committee's report with a bang and give in to pressure from some people who think that the committee should not be in a position to act on the information that is in it."
The Independent Parliamentary Standards Authority said it could not comment on individual issues.
The committee has not heard from Mr Johnson since the last meeting, which was in February, when it was told it would not be allowed to publish the emails.

The committee then was given only five minutes to respond to a letter it received from Mr Johnson's sister, Heidi, which said: "The committee has received this letter. You have no right to be involved in any of the decisions the committee has made.
